awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation (NSF) Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) project at Southern Illinois University Carbondale in Carbondale, Illinois will provide scholarships for talented, low-income students with demonstrated financial need who are pursuing STEM degrees. The program, called Pathways to STEM Leadership (PSL), will improve the recruitment, retention, graduation rates, and job placement of community college students transferring to Southern Illinois University Carbondale STEM colleges. The program is designed help STEM students become future leaders in industry by providing them with leadership training, mentoring, a cohort experience, and community service opportunities. The development of technical leaders has become a critical need for the United States in helping to maintain a competitive position in a technology-based global economy. Scholarships and support for low-income and academically talented students, who may not otherwise be able to obtain STEM degrees, will help to produce a well-trained workforce that will contribute to the economic well-being of the nation.

The project will conduct research to determine the influence of formal and experiential leadership training opportunities on student persistence and completion of STEM degrees. This work is based on the results of a prior NSF S-STEM project that emphasized the development of leadership skills. That project resulted in high rates of degree completion and successful entry into the workforce by low-income students in the college of engineering. This project will utilize a matched control group to help identify the impact of cohort-based leadership training on factors such as persistence, grades, graduation rate, and placement upon graduation.  The project responds to a need expressed by technology-driven companies for improved technical leadership skills in graduates entering the workforce. The findings from the program will be disseminated widely to the STEM education community.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF SOUTHERN ILLINOIS UNIVERSITY

por.por_cntn:
The Pathways to STEM Leadership (PSL) at Southern Illinois University (SIU) Carbondale is a distinguished S-STEM scholarship initiative focused on building a collaborative community of scholars. The program, rooted in the Leadership Development Program (LDP) within SIU's College of Engineering, aims to attract academically talented and economically disadvantaged students from partner community colleges to SIU as STEM majors. The goal is to train these students as technical leaders.

Since its inception, the PSL program has awarded 44 scholarships to STEM majors, guiding them to successful graduation. Impressively, 100% of the scholars completing the PSL program remained at the university and graduated, surpassing non-PSL students by 25%. This accomplishment highlights the program's positive impact on academic success and student persistence in STEM fields.

Beyond graduation rates, PSL scholarship students demonstrated substantial growth in Leadership Self-efficacy and Motivation to Lead, showcasing statistically higher scores compared to pre-survey results and a control group. This indicates that PSL not only contributes to academic success but also plays a crucial role in fostering leadership skills and motivation among participants. Moreover, PSL graduates exhibited higher scores on the Grit-S Scale and the Job Readiness Scale, affirming the program's positive influence on traits associated with perseverance and workforce readiness.

The unanimous agreement among 100% of students and faculty regarding the value of the STEM program reflects the widespread support for PSL within the academic community. Despite the challenges posed by COVID, the program successfully pivoted post-pandemic, utilizing leadership training and lessons learned.

The culmination of the PSL program not only showcases individual triumphs but also suggests a potential societal benefit. The program's success in augmenting grit and job readiness becomes a beacon of hope for broader societal advancement within the STEM field.

In instilling grit, PSL cultivates a resilient mindset crucial for addressing challenges in STEM fields collaboratively. This mindset extends beyond personal success to become a collective force for societal progress. As participants learn to navigate setbacks with determination, they become agents of positive change, contributing to the resilience necessary for addressing global challenges.

Equally significant is the program's impact on job readiness. STEM careers require not only technical proficiency but also a holistic skill set, including effective communication and leadership. PSL's strategic approach ensures that STEM graduates are well-prepared for interdisciplinary collaborations and communicating findings to diverse audiences.

The societal implications of cultivating grit and job readiness through STEM leadership programs are profound. In a world marked by rapid technological advancements, resilient and versatile professionals become drivers of societal advancement. These professionals contribute not only to their respective fields but also serve as catalysts for innovation, addressing complex issues beyond disciplinary boundaries.

Furthermore, the program's focus on holistic skill development contributes to a socially aware and ethically responsible STEM workforce. Graduates possess the knowledge to advance technology and the interpersonal skills to collaborate effectively and consider the broader societal impact of their work.

As PSL graduates enter the workforce, they carry the transformative power of grit and a well-rounded skill set crucial for societal progress. Their influence extends beyond individual careers, contributing to the collective pursuit of knowledge and innovation, shaping a future where STEM is a force for societal well-being.

In conclusion, the Pathways to STEM Leadership Program has significantly impacted student success, leadership development, and overall program value. Positive outcomes in retention rates, academic performance, and leadership skills position PSL as a successful model for enhancing STEM education and preparing future leaders in the field.

 


Last Modified: 01/07/2024
Modified by: Bruce D Deruntz
